fields.description:
h3. Summary
 
Comment can end up on the wrong line when one user makes a comment on a file while the second user is changing the file.
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 
Steps to duplicate issue:
# Create repository with a text file in it that is more than 1 line.  I duplicated with 10 lines.  This session will be called the terminal session.
# Create a branch in the terminal session and push to Bitbucket.
# Change file by duplicating the first line of the file.  There should be two identical lines at the beginning of the file.
# Push changes to Bitbucket and create a pull request.  This will be called the web session.
# Start a comment on line 2.  Do *not* click the comment button.
# In the terminal session, add a third line that is identical to the first two lines.  The first three lines should be identical. 
# Add some text to the beginning of the Second line.
# Save changes.  git add, commit, push change.
# Wait for the rescope of the pull request in Bitbucket.
# Click the Comment button in the web session.
# Reload web session.  Comment will be on second line.  The third line, the intended line, will not have a comment.
fields.summary: Comment ends up on unintended line.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

At the moment, deleting a branch as part of merging a pull request does not trigger the {{BranchDeletedEvent}} although https://docs.atlassian.com/bitbucket-server/javadoc/5.16.0/api/reference/com/atlassian/bitbucket/event/branch/BranchDeletedEvent.html states

{quote}
An event that is raised when a branch is deleted using the UI or REST
{quote}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Delete a branch explicitly (i.e. outside of merging a pull request) and observe the BranchDeletedEvent is fired
# Merge a pull request and tick the box to delete the source branch, and observe the BranchDeletedEvent is not fired although the deletion happened through the UI and should therefore be fired according to the documentation
fields.summary: BranchDeletedEvent is not fired when deleting a branch as part of a pull request merge

The current API's for creating pull request and commit comments (both REST and Java) do not support a "date" field but instead always use the current date. It would be very useful to have a "date" parameter for purposes like importing comments from 3rd party systems to have a correct timeline.

Thanks,
Michael

fields.description:
*NOTE:* Atlassian support specifically instructed me to file a bug report here. Jira prevented me from categorizing it as a bug, insisting that I contact support instead. There seems to be a lot of confusion regarding the process for entering legitimate bugs into this tracker.

We're an Electron app and we're using XMLHttpRequest because then the behavior vis-a-vis SSL certificates and proxy settings are identical to Chrome, which is immensely helpful to our end users because as long as they can reach their Bitbucket instance in Chrome, they know that our Electron app's API integration will also work without a lot of extra configuration.

We're trying to use Personal Access Tokens to talk to the REST API for Bitbucket Server (v5.15.0) and getting back a 500. The issue seems to be that the {{Origin}} header sent by Electron is {{[file://|file:///]}} because Electron apps are not actually websites.

[The relevant line|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/application-links/src/e71fdba136567ed9b04066a3bcfc7befdb818689/applinks-cors-plugin/src/main/java/com/atlassian/applinks/cors/auth/DefaultCorsService.java?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#DefaultCorsService.java-50] appears to throw the origin header straight into {{java.net.URI.create}}, and since {{[file://|file:///]}} isn't much of a URI, it makes sense that Java is throwing an error. Note that we have a default installation with no special CORS settings.

Unfortunately, XHR is fundamentally a browser technology, and as such changing the origin header is [forbidden|https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Forbidden_header_name] to prevent cross-site attacks.

We are currently investigating using an API exposed in Electron but not exposed to browsers, which lets us do unsafe things, but a simple XHR call ought to work. Regardless of our particular issue, a well-configured server should never throw a Java error and return a 500 if it can help it, no matter how awful the request headers are.

The full stack trace follows:
{code:java}

    at com.google.common.collect.Iterables.any(Iterables.java:623)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:24)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:24)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:24)

fields.description:
h3.  Problem 

Make alert "Alert: Bitbucket is reaching resource limits." visible only to administrators

In many cases displaying this alert to all user can create more overhead for administrators trying to resolve the problem. The main reason for this that it generates a lot addition support requests.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow banner to be hidden or make only visible to admins

h3. Workaround
It is possible to disable the performance warning banner per the [server busy configuration properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/configuration-properties-776640155.html#Configurationproperties-Serverbusybanners].
# Must modify BITBUCKET_HOME/shared/bitbucket.properties
# Add the following:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
# Controls how long a warning banner is displayed in the UI after a request is rejected due to excessive load.
# This value is in minutes. Using 0, or a negative value, disables displaying the banner.
server.busy.on.ticket.rejected.within=0
{code}
# Restart Bitbucket for the changes to take affect

(!) This does not disable it for standard users to make it visible for administrators. This completely disables the warning banner. Only proceed if you have other monitoring controls in place for the hosting, command, and ref tickets.
fields.summary: Make alert "Alert: Bitbucket is reaching resource limits." visible only to administrators

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bitbucket administrators are unable to revoke authorized applications globally for all users. Instead, each user must go to their profile in Bitbucket Server and remove the authorized application (check attached screenshot).
h3. Suggested Solution

Give administrators control to bulk delete/revoke authorized applications for users.
h3. Why this is important

Whenever the linked server does not exist anymore in the environment, users will have to individually revoke access to that server which will be a tedious and manual job for the administrator.
fields.summary: Revoke authorized applications globally for all users

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Vendor requesting to have a patch API in Bitbucket Server just like what we have for [cloud|https://bitbucket.org/!api/2.0/repositories/atlassian/aui/patch/atlassian/aui:2fc790c4baf7%0Da193814bcef6]

Currently, vendor is limited to using [this|https://docs.atlassian.com/bitbucket-server/rest/5.15.1/bitbucket-rest.html#idm46054335391504] API because it's the closest API to retrieve commit/pull-request diff for server:
{quote}
Git patch is a standard format and a lot of libraries exist to parse and make sense of it. All major platforms (GitHub, Gitlab, Bitbucket cloud) provide an API to retrieve git patches, so this should be extended to Bitbucket Server as well.
{quote}

Use case defined in: [DEVHELP-1944|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/DEVHELP-1944]
fields.summary: Request patch API in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
On the [Markdown syntax guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/markdown-syntax-guide-776639995.html], we mention the below:
{quote}README files
 If your repository contains a *README.md* file at the root level, Bitbucket Server displays its contents on the repository's Source page if the file has the .md extension. The file can containMarkdown and a restricted set of HTML tags.
{quote}
However, we currently apply MarkDown formatting to the following file extensions:
{noformat}
.md
.mkd
.mkdn
.mdown
.markdown 
.text 
.txt
{noformat}
For plaintext files, the expectation is that there is no formatting / parsing done, and that the file is rendered as-is in a fixed-width font.

Additionally the documentation should be amended to reflect the additional file extensions that can be used to ensure a file is parsed through the MarkDown formatter.
fields.summary: Don't apply MarkDown formatting to plain text files

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Upon starting up a single instance from the cluster which has been upgraded or not being upgraded, it would be better to look into more trace or GUI stating the version mismatch rather than {{SpringMVC dispatcher [springMvc] could not be started}} trace in the log.

h3. Step to Reproduce
h5. Scenario 1:
# Assuming all three nodes are on version 5.15.0.
# Unintentionally forgotten to bring down all the nodes.
# Only one node is brought down and upgrade to version 5.15.1 then immediately restarted

h5. Scenario 2:
# Assuming all three nodes are on version 5.15.0.
# All there nodes were brought down.
# Upgrade is done on two nodes only while one node is left out.

h3. Expected Results
GUI warning stating there is a mismatch version on the cluster or start-up trace stating on the mismatched version.

h3. Actual Results
Error trace on the log:
{noformat}
2018-11-14 15:46:43,713 ERROR [spring-startup] c.a.j.s.w.s.JohnsonDispatcherServlet SpringMVC dispatcher [springMvc] could not be started
org.springframework.beans.factory.UnsatisfiedDependencyException: Error creating bean with name 'crowdAliasDao': Unsatisfied dependency expressed through method 'setSessionFactory' parameter 0; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'hazelcast' defined in class path resource [stash-context.xml]: Invocation of init method failed; nested exception is com.atlassian.stash.internal.cluster.NodePassivationException: The current node has been passivated
{noformat}

h5. NOTE
The Bitbucket Data Center is expected to bring for the upgrade - [Can Bitbucket Data Center be upgraded without downtime (i.e., a rolling upgrade)?|https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/bitbucket-data-center-faq-776663707.html#BitbucketDataCenterFAQ-CanBitbucketDataCenterbeupgradedwithoutdowntime(i.e.,arollingupgrade)?]
fields.summary: Better information on starting up mismatched instance from cluster

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce
 # Setup a Bitbucket Server connected to a supported Postgres database
 # Create a plugin with 6 or more upgrade tasks on the same entity (e.g.: renaming a column each time)
 # Install the plugin on the running Bitbucket Server instance

Expected: The plugin installs without any problems

Actual: The plugin fails to be installed and a {{PSQLException}} can be found in the logs with the message: _ERROR: cached plan must not change result type_

{code:java}
Caused by: org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: cached plan must not change result type
        at org.postgresql.core.v3.QueryExecutorImpl.receiveErrorResponse(QueryExecutorImpl.java:2477)
        at org.postgresql.core.v3.QueryExecutorImpl.processResults(QueryExecutorImpl.java:2190)
        at org.postgresql.core.v3.QueryExecutorImpl.execute(QueryExecutorImpl.java:300)
        at org.postgresql.jdbc.PgStatement.executeInternal(PgStatement.java:428)
        at org.postgresql.jdbc.PgStatement.execute(PgStatement.java:354)
        at org.postgresql.jdbc.PgPreparedStatement.executeWithFlags(PgPreparedStatement.java:169)
        at org.postgresql.jdbc.PgPreparedStatement.executeQuery(PgPreparedStatement.java:117)
        at net.java.ao.schema.helper.DatabaseMetaDataReaderImpl.getResultSetMetaData(DatabaseMetaDataReaderImpl.java:265)
        at net.java.ao.schema.helper.DatabaseMetaDataReaderImpl.getFields(DatabaseMetaDataReaderImpl.java:89)
        ... 37 common frames omitted
{code}

h2. Detailed description

Postgres databases can use server side prepared statements as a performance optimisation for query execution.

The [Postgres JDBC|https://jdbc.postgresql.org/documentation/head/server-prepare.html] driver supports server side prepared statements. Users can configure a {{prepareThreshold}} and once a query has been executed more than the specified threshold ({{5}} by default) the driver will start running it with server side prepared statements.

However server side prepared statements don't support queries of the type {{SELECT * ...}} executed in the same transaction as a DDL query (e.g.: {{ALTER <TABLE_NAME> ADD column ...}}). This causes an error with the message: _"cached plan must not change result type"_.

While running upgrade tasks, Active Objects will run {{SELECT * FROM <TABLE_NAME> LIMIT 1}} queries in order to "read the schema" causing the above mentioned error when the table is migrated.
h2. Workaround

Customers who are running into this issue while trying to install a plugin can, as a workaround, increase the value of the prepared threshold to complete the installation. This will require:
 # Stop Bitbucket Server
 # Changing the {{jdbc.url}} parameter to add a {{prepareThreshold}} parameter (e.g.: {{jdbc.url=jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/bitbucket?prepareThreshold=10}})
 # Start Bitbucket Server
 # Install the plugin
 # Stop Bitbucket Server
 # Changing the {{jdbc.url}} parameter to remove the {{prepareThreshold}} parameter
 # Start Bitbucket Server

*NOTE:* *Server side prepared statements are a performance optimisation and there may performance impacts when running with a value which differs from the default configuration***

Tested on Bitbucket Server 5.15 with Postgres 9.6.
fields.summary: Multiple AO upgrade tasks fail on Postgres

fields.description:
Apologies because I want to make a suggestion for Bitbucket cloud, but there is no Jira Project available for this product.

When a file is too big to be displayed in a pull request, the page shows a message "Oops! You've got a lot of code in this diff and it couldn't load with the page." instead of the actually diff. This is understandable, but what happens is that this message appears for each subsequent file in the pull request, even if all remaining files have small diffs.

What would be better is if the page recognized the large diff, showed the message like it does today, but continued rendering the rest of the diffs.

In my particular case, the large file is a _package-lock.json_ for npm. An alternative approach to addressing this issue would be to recognize common files that typically suffer from large diffs and automatically hide them and show some message like "Diffs for files of this type are typically too big to display, so it's hidden by default."

Thanks!
fields.summary: Improvement for when a file is too big to display in a pull request

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

A shared {{ScheduledExecutorService}} is made available for add-ons to use, and add-on developers are encouraged to use it instead of, for example, doing heavy processing directly in event listeners (which are invoked on a limited number of dispatcher threads).

However, there are some core part of the application that are _also_ using the same shared executor.
 That means if add-ons invoke particularly slow/heavy operations on the shared executor, it can block the operation that the core part of the application is performing.

So far, this problem has been observed in the following functionalities:
 - Time outs when displaying branches:
{noformat}
c.a.s.i.r.PluginRefMetadataMapProvider Timed out when retrieving ref metadata for com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-jira:branch-list-jira-issues
c.a.s.i.r.PluginRefMetadataMapProvider Timed out when retrieving ref metadata for com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-branch:ahead-behind-metadata-provider
c.a.s.i.r.PluginRefMetadataMapProvider Timed out when retrieving ref metadata for com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-branch:latest-commit-metadata
c.a.s.i.r.PluginRefMetadataMapProvider Timed out when retrieving ref metadata for com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-build:build-status-metadata
{noformat}

 - -HookService, which handles pre-receive and post-receive callbacks from pushes, to cause slow pushes- (Handled separately on BSERV-10652)
 - Diff transcoding triggering a backlog of {{transcode.pl}} processes, which may manifest as slow blame or diff views
 - Processing notifications to create emails

h3. Common Misconceptions

Sending email is _not_ handled by the shared {{ScheduledExecutorService}}. It's handled by a separate, dedicated executor which, by default, has a single thread. If emails are building up in the queue the number of threads dedicated to sending emails can be increased by adding an entry like the following in {{bitbucket.properties}} and restarting Bitbucket Server:
{code:java}
mail.threads=4 {code}
Note that 4 is just an example, not a recommendation.
h3. Suggested Solution

The affected services should be updated to use their own executor. This would ensure that their processing would not be delayed by other parts of the system.
h3. Workaround

Disable/uninstall the add on causing the high and slow usage of the shared executor.
fields.summary: Provide an isolated executor for Bitbucket core logic instead of relying on the ScheduledExecutorService

fields.description:
There is currently a problem with stopping Bitbucket server instance in data center:
While starting a bitbucket server instance with "start-bitbucket.sh" in DataCenter supports "--no-search" option to not start a local elastic-search instance, the "stop-bitbucket.sh" does not support such an option.

As a result the script does successfully stops the bitbucket instance, but then tries to stop the not-existent elasticsearch instance resulting in an errorcode.

As a consequence, using the script in initd/systemd the "systemctl stop bitbucket" will "fail" and the service is marked as "failed", even if was successfully stopped. This is a very annoying situation.

Example of /etc/systemd/system/bitbucket.service:
{code:java}
[Unit]
Description=Bitbucket
After=syslog.target network.target[Service]
Type=forking
User=bitbucket
Environment=JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/default
PIDFile=/var/opt/atlassian/bitbucket/log/bitbucket.pid
ExecStart=/opt/atlassian/bitbucket/bitbucket_current/bin/start-bitbucket.sh --no-search
ExecStop=/opt/atlassian/bitbucket/bitbucket_current/bin/stop-bitbucket.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
 {code}
As in "start-bitbucket.sh" the "--no-search" should be implemented in stop-Bitbucket and - if set - skip the part to stop the (non-exsitent) local elasticsearch instance.
fields.summary: "bitbucket-stop.sh" does not support "--no-search"

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If something is going wrong with the synchronization of the repositories it's impossible to discover from the UI to determine which repositories (projects) are impacted as the status bar is shown for all the synchronization scope.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the status check for each project (repository) to determine the scope of the impact before getting reports from the end users.
h3. Why this is important
It will help the administrator of Bitbucket instance to be more proactive in troubleshooting Smart Mirroring issues.
fields.summary: Provide better status interface for the mirror

fields.description:
It is possible for instances of ServletInputStream to be used in handling one request after Tomcat has recycled (i.e. reused) the stream for a different request.

Symptoms include, but are not limited to:
 * Incorrect user agent reported in access logs. For example where an user agent "git/2.16.55" is reported where it should be "git/2.16.5"
 * Incorrect client IP address reported in access logs. This will typically, like the user agent, involved the final character being repeated.
 * Users interacting with the user interface experience failures with error "You've switched users"
fields.summary: ServletInputStream use after stream has been recycled

fields.description:
Currently, a pull request is expected to have every reviewer review it before it is merged, but this means that a pull request can be held up by a single reviewer who is unable to review it.

It would be nice to have some sort of feature to allow us to specify all the people who may review a pull request and then separately specify the number of people required to approve it before merging.
fields.summary: Specify desired number of pull request approvals

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When the JIRA issue created using the form from the diff comment in pull request the new JIRA issue is created but not linked to the PR from where it originated.

h3. Environment
JIRA 7.12.3
Bitbucket 5.15.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create JIRA issue
# Create a branch from JIRA using the issue key 
# Make some new commits to the repository
# Create PR to merge the branch into another
# Open a file in diff view
# Add a comment to a diff
# Fill the form to create a JIRA issue


h3. Expected Results
JIRA issue is created and linked to original PR
h3. Actual Results
The issue is created but no reference for the original PR. No activity in the logs with the new issue key discovered.

Moreover, the mentioning the new issue in the comment does not create a mentioning on JIRA side either.

fields.description: Bitbucket Server now supports a multitude of merge strategies. We use the Rebase strategy, and extensively use "git commit --fixup" when resolving issues found in the review, but since there is no way of enabling --autosquash, we are forced to first to a "git rebase --autosquash master" locally, then force-push it to BitBucket, and then finally merge. It would be very convenient if Bitbucket had a merge strategy that did autosquash automatically.
fields.summary: Add rebase with autosquash as merge strategy

fields.description:
Hi Team

After opening a Pull Request for two branches, merging them locally with --FF first and pushing them to Bitbucket, the open PR should be merged remotely.

This works correctly in Linux, however, in Windows (tested in Windows Server and Windows 10), the pull request is not merged until the next commit to the base branch.
Consider this scenario:
{code:java}
1.	Create branch B from R, synch repo locally
2.	Commit locally to R, push R
3.	Commit locally to B, push B
4.	Merge from R to B locally, push B
5.	Create Pull Request from B to R at bitbucket
6.	Commit R locally, push R
7.	Commit R locally, push R (second time)
8.	Merge R to B locally, push B
9.	Merge B to R using FF (fast-forward) locally, push R
{code}
Now, the PR behavior after step 9 differs between Windows and Linux.

*In Linux:*
The PR created in step 5 is merged.

*In Windows:*
The PR remains open until the next commit to R is pushed to Bitbucket again.

You can use these scripts to reproduce the scenario:
(prerequisite: create a new branch from a base one)

*Linux, script 1 (before PR creation):*
{code:java}
echo "Starting processing 1st stage. Base branch: "$1"; side branch: "$2"; folder processed: "$3""

repo=$3
releaseBranch=$1
sideBranch=$2

cd $repo

echo As before step 1 please create branch $sideBranch at remote repo
echo _
echo Step 1: Getting remote branch $sideBranch

git fetch
git checkout $sideBranch

echo Step 2.1 Switch to $releaseBranch

git checkout $releaseBranch

echo Step 2.2 Commit locally to $releaseBranch

echo Branch $releaseBranch step 2 $(date) >> releasework.txt

git add .
git commit -m "Step 2, commit to $releaseBranch"

echo Step 2.3 Push $releaseBranch to origin

git push origin $releaseBranch

echo Step 3.1: Commit locally to $sideBranch 

git checkout $sideBranch

echo Branch $sideBranch step 3 $(date) >> branchwork.txt

git add .
git commit -m "Step 3, commit to $sideBranch"

echo Step 3.2: Push $sideBranch to origin

git push origin $sideBranch

echo Step 4.1 merge $releaseBranch $sideBranch

git merge $releaseBranch -m "Step 4 merge $releaseBranch to $sideBranch"

echo Step 4.2 Push $sideBranch

git push origin $sideBranch

echo Right now we are right before the step 5 - please start the pull request from $sideBranch to $releaseBranch
cd ..
{code}
*Linux, script2 (after PR creation):*
{code:java}
@ECHO OFF
echo Starting processing 2nd stage. Original branch: "$1" side branch: "$2" folder processed: "$3"

repo=$3
releaseBranch=$1
sideBranch=$2
cd $repo

echo "I hope you haven't forgot to create pull request at BB from "$sideBranch" to "$releaseBranc""
echo _

echo Step 6.1 Switch to $releaseBranch

git checkout $releaseBranch

echo Step 6.2 Commit locally to $releaseBranch

echo Branch $releaseBranch step 6 $(date)  >> releasework.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Step 6, commit to $releaseBranch"

echo Step 6.3 Push $releaseBranch to origin

git push origin $releaseBranch

echo Step 7.1 Switch to $releaseBranch

git checkout $releaseBranch

echo Step 7.2 Commit locally to $releaseBranch

echo Branch $releaseBranch step 7 $(date) >> releasework.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Step 7, commit to $releaseBranch"

echo Step 7.3 Push $releaseBranch to origin

git push origin $releaseBranch

echo Step 8.1 merge $releaseBranch $sideBranch

git checkout $sideBranch
git merge $releaseBranch -m "Step 8 merge $releaseBranch to $sideBranch"

echo Step 8.2 Push $sideBranch

git push origin $sideBranch 

echo Step 9 - merge to $releaseBranch using ff strategy and spoil pull request

pause
git checkout $releaseBranch
git merge $sideBranch --ff-only
git push origin $releaseBranch

echo "RIght here the pull request should be merged."

cd ..
{code}
*Windows, script 1 (pre-PR):*
{code:java}
@ECHO OFF
echo Starting processing 1st stage. Original branch: "%1"; side branch: "%2"; folder processed: "%3"

SET repo=%3
SET releaseBranch=%1
SET sideBranch=%2
cd %repo%

echo As before step 1 please create branch %sideBranch% at remote repo
echo _
echo Step 1: Getting remote branch %sideBranch%

git fetch
git checkout %sideBranch%

echo Step 2.1 Switch to %releaseBranch%

git checkout %releaseBranch%

echo Step 2.2 Commit locally to %releaseBranch%

echo Branch %releaseBranch% step 2 %date% %time% >> releasework.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Step 2, commit to %releaseBranch%"

echo Step 2.3 Push %releaseBranch% to origin

git push origin %releaseBranch%

echo Step 3.1: Commit locally to %sideBranch% 

git checkout %sideBranch%

echo Branch %sideBranch% step 3 %date% %time% >> branchwork.txt

git add .
git commit -m "Step 3, commit to %sideBranch%"

echo Step 3.2: Push %sideBranch% to origin

git push origin %sideBranch%

echo Step 4.1 merge %releaseBranch% %sideBranch%

git merge %releaseBranch% -m "Step 4 merge %releaseBranch% to %sideBranch%"

echo Step 4.2 Push %sideBranch%

git push origin %sideBranch% 

echo Right now we are right before the step 5 - please start the pull request from %sideBranch% to %releaseBranch%

cd ..
{code}
*Windows, script 2 (after PR creation):*
{code:java}
@ECHO OFF
echo Starting processing 2nd stage. Original branch: "%1"; side branch: "%2"; folder processed: "%3"

SET repo=%3
SET releaseBranch=%1
SET sideBranch=%2
cd %repo%

echo I hope you haven't forgot to create pull request at BB from "%sideBranch%" to "%releaseBranc%"
echo _

echo Step 6.1 Switch to %releaseBranch%

git checkout %releaseBranch%

echo Step 6.2 Commit locally to %releaseBranch%

echo Branch %releaseBranch% step 6 %date% %time% >> releasework.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Step 6, commit to %releaseBranch%"

echo Step 6.3 Push %releaseBranch% to origin

git push origin %releaseBranch%

echo Step 7.1 Switch to %releaseBranch%

git checkout %releaseBranch%

echo Step 7.2 Commit locally to %releaseBranch%

echo Branch %releaseBranch% step 7 %date% %time% >> releasework.txt
git add .
git commit -m "Step 7, commit to %releaseBranch%"

echo Step 7.3 Push %releaseBranch% to origin

git push origin %releaseBranch%

echo Step 8.1 merge %releaseBranch% %sideBranch%

git checkout %sideBranch%
git merge %releaseBranch% -m "Step 8 merge %releaseBranch% to %sideBranch%"

echo Step 8.2 Push %sideBranch%

git push origin %sideBranch% 

echo Step 9 - merge to %releaseBranch% using ff strategy and spoil pull request
pause
git checkout %releaseBranch%
git merge %sideBranch% --ff-only
git push origin %releaseBranch%

echo RIght here the pull request should be spoiled - or not ;)

cd ..
{code}
In Windows, to merge the Pull Request created in 5., you need to push an additional, unrelated commit to the base branch. PR will be merged then, but the author merging the branch will be pulled from that last commit, not from the commit that merged the PR.

Please find two attached Support Zips, for Windows and Linux.
I've tested it in Windows 2012, Windows 10, Git 2.16.1, Git 2.18.0. The behavior is the same in each configuration.

Tested in Bitbucket 5.1, 5.10, 5.11, 5.14 and 5.15.

 

Best regards,
Tomasz Tokarczuk
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Pull Request auto merging doesn't always work in Windows

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a user is deleted from a user directory connected to Bitbucket as a delegated one ([Delegating Bitbucket Server authentication to an LDAP directory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/delegating-bitbucket-server-authentication-to-an-ldap-directory-776640402.html]), users are not removed automatically when they are disabled or deleted from the user directory.

From the documentation:
{quote}
If you need to delete a user, do it on the LDAP server, but also in the application. If you delete the user only on the LDAP server, it will be rejected from logging in to the application, but it won't be set as inactive, which will affect your license. You'll need to disable the *Update User attributes on Login* option to delete the user, and then enable it again.
{quote}

Bitbucket administrators have to delete these users manually or set up an automated process to do so.

These users are a problem because:
- they count as an active license
- they are not in the LDAP user directory anymore so are not part of the company anymore, so users in Bitbucket will diverge from the ones in LDAP
- in case these users had an ssh key and that's still used to authenticate, the logs will report the following {{git was successfully authenticated via public key, but is no longer active in the underlying user directory. The request has been blocked}}

h3. Suggested Solution
Automatically remove these users from Bitbucket once they are not available in the delegated user directory.

h3. Workaround
Delete the users manually or set up an automated process to do so.

+Automatic process flow example+
- check for the user existence and status in the user directory (e.g. LDAP)
- the {{DELETE /REST/API/1.0/ADMIN/USERS?NAME}} endpoint can be used to delete users (see [REST Resources Provided By: Bitbucket Server|https://docs.atlassian.com/bitbucket-server/rest/latest/bitbucket-rest.html] for details)
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like users available in Bitbucket via a delegated user directory to be automatically removed

fields.description:
When I'm reviewing a pull request, there are times when I would like to add a private note, task, or bookmark (or something else) related to a piece of code. This is often useful if I want to come back to a piece of code after reviewing other parts first, perhaps because it may refer to another related class that I want to review first.

Existing alternatives:
 * Use a comment - visible to everyone and would just be noise at that point as it may not actually be an issue
 * Make a note outside the pull request - difficult to link to a specific section of code
 * Create a comment, but leave it in draft - hard to find later and has the potential to be saved for everyone
fields.summary: Provide a way for a reviewer to make private notes, tasks, or bookmarks in a pull request

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Downloading source cannot be disabled:
!image-2018-10-30-11-53-51-478.png|thumbnail! 

The [properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html#BitbucketServerconfigproperties-Downloads] allow defining policies to control what can be downloaded, but do not allow disabling downloads. 

Customers might consider that a security breach and might want to block downloading source.

h3. Suggested Solution
There should be a way of disabling source download altogether, maybe via properties file.

h3. Workaround
There are currently no workarounds.
fields.summary: Allow removing the Download link

fields.description:
If the Pull Request Commit Backfill Job completely fails it is required to have Bitbucket restarted to trigger it again. 

The problem arises if you have a few bad repositories and need to perform a manual workaround to remove them, where you need to wait for the job to fail and then capture the repository under <bitbucket-home>/shared/config/upgrades/core-backfill-pull-request-commits to have it skipped, where you need to restart Bitbucket every single time.

Please add an easier way of restarting this job.
fields.summary: Please add a simpler way of restarting the Pull Request Commit Backfill Job

h3. Problem Definition
Bitbucket currently logs only web application logins in the user management in "Last authenticated" column of the Users interface. So the users who have never logged in to UI but logged in with git HTTPS or SSH are showing as "unknown"

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement the logging for git logins

h3. Why this is important
 It will allow the administrator to track the inactive users not only on UI activity but git as well.

h3. Workaround 
Currently, the information can be fetched only from the audit logs.
fields.summary: Log git logins as well in "last authenticated" column in user management

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Server, there is currently no way to disable or hide the ability to download archives from a repository in the Web UI.  

This is the feature described here:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/download-an-archive-from-bitbucket-server-913477030.html

Example Use case:

Customer is hosted at an external provider and want to be able to restrict the ability of code to be downloaded to be only within their network while at the same time allowing for UI access over the web for devs to do code reviews and such. 

The ability to restrict SSH and HTTP to the /scm path for the git clones to not be available except via the internal network interface can be accomplished, but the download feature via the UI provides for a full download of source which would in-turn prevent the customer from making the UI available over a web level connection.
fields.summary: Provide a way to Disable Download Archives from the UI

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Considering that users can be programmatically created or provisioned from external user directory systems and that once the license count is exceeded Bitbucket becomes Read-Only, it is critical to monitor the license usage to quickly react when the active users is approaching the threshold or it is reached.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide JMX counters for monitoring the license details.

For example, [Jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/live-monitoring-using-the-jmx-interface-939707304.html] exposes the {{jira.license}} counter which provides the following:
{quote}
The types of licenses you have, the number of active users, and the maximum number of users available for each license type.
{quote}

h3. Workaround
The [Bitbucket REST API|https://docs.atlassian.com/bitbucket-server/rest/latest/bitbucket-rest.html] provides an endpoint to query for licensed users.

Here is an example
{noformat}
$ ADMIN_USER=admin
$ ADMIN_PASS=admin
$ curl -u $ADMIN_USER:$ADMIN_PASS -X GET <bitbucket_url>/rest/api/1.0/users?permission=LICENSED_USER > /tmp/users
{noformat}

More options are available on the [How do I find which users count against my bitbucket server license|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/how-do-i-find-which-users-count-against-my-bitbucket-server-license-779171685.html] article.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like to monitor the license count via JMX

fields.description:
h3. Summary
An installed Bundled JRE does not get updated when an installer with a newer Bundled JRE is run. This is for an update or install on a system with no manual or custom install of Java. This means once a Bundled JRE is installed, Bitbucket will use only this version until a user upgrade/installs Java manually.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bitbucket Server using the installer on a system without Java.
# Upgrade Bitbucket Server to a newer version / install a fresh Bitbucket server instance using an installer with a newer JRE bundled.

h3. Expected Results
# The installed Bundled JRE should have been upgraded to the newer Bundled JRE

h3. Actual Results
# The installer uses the old JRE location and does not extract the newer JRE

h3.Workaround
Install the new JRE version manually.
fields.summary: Installer does not upgrade existing installed Bundled JRE's

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Unexpected notes and v* (e.g. v0, v1, ..., v99) folders are present in the git repositories in Bitbucket Server.

These can cause the Bitbucket to stop attempting to run git garbage collection on the repositories and the following message being logged in the {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} file:
{noformat}
Abandoning garbage collection after 3 failed attempts
com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.CommandFailedException: '/bib/git/bin/git repack -A -d -l -n --unpack-unreachable=72.hours.ago' exited with code 128 saying: fatal: bad object refs/pull-requests/<pr_id>/v22
{noformat}


h3. Steps to Reproduce
Unknown so far

h3. Expected Results
No unexpected folders are present in the git repositories by Bitbucket Server.

h3. Actual Results
Repositories contain unexpected folders:
- {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/data/repositories/<repository_id>/refs/pull-requests/notes}}
- {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/data/repositories/<repository_id>/refs/pull-requests/<pr_id>/v*}}

And the git garbage collection fails with the following message:
{noformat}
Abandoning garbage collection after 3 failed attempts
com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.CommandFailedException: '/bib/git/bin/git repack -A -d -l -n --unpack-unreachable=72.hours.ago' exited with code 128 saying: fatal: bad object refs/pull-requests/<pr_id>/v22
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Reach out to Atlassian Support for assistance on how to manually remove the unexpected folders.
fields.summary: Unexpected refs/pull-requests/notes and refs/pull-requests/<pr_id>/v* (e.g. v0, v1, ..., v99) folders are present in the git repositories in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
To reproduce:
 # Link Jira Software Server v7.11.1 with Bitbucket Server v5.14.0.
 # In Jira, create an issue with the summary "Access check consumes O(n²) memory". This summary includes the character U+00B2 SUPERSCRIPT TWO.
 # In Jira, view the issue.
 # In Jira, click "Create Branch" under the "Development" heading.
 # The browser opens the page [http://bitbucket.example:7990/plugins/servlet/create-branch?issueKey=TESTCR-2253&issueType=Bug&issueSummary=Access+check+consumes+O%28n%C2%B2%29+memory]. The issueSummary parameter of this URL contains an encoding of U+00B2 SUPERSCRIPT TWO.

Actual result:
 * Bitbucket Server deletes U+00B2 SUPERSCRIPT TWO and suggests this branch name: TESTCR-2253-access-check-consumes-o-n-memory

Desired result:
 * Bitbucket Server should replace U+00B2 SUPERSCRIPT TWO with U+0032 DIGIT TWO and suggest this branch name: TESTCR-2253-access-check-consumes-o-n2-memory

Workaround:
 * Edit the branch name, instead of accepting the suggestion as is.

Bitbucket Server already replaces some other characters: it replaces "ä" to "a", and "ö" with "o". I would like it to also replace the following characters, rather than delete them:
||Character||Replacement||
|"⁰" U+2070 SUPERSCRIPT ZERO|​"0" U+0030 DIGIT ZERO|
|"¹" U+00B9 SUPERSCRIPT ONE|"1" U+0031 DIGIT ONE|
|"²" U+00B2 SUPERSCRIPT TWO|"2" U+0032 DIGIT TWO|
|"³" U+00B3 SUPERSCRIPT THREE|"3" U+0033 DIGIT THREE|
|"⁴" U+2074 SUPERSCRIPT FOUR|"4" U+0034 DIGIT FOUR|
|"⁵" U+2075 SUPERSCRIPT FIVE|"5" U+0035 DIGIT FIVE|
|"⁶" U+2076 SUPERSCRIPT SIX|"6" U+0036 DIGIT SIX|
|"⁷" U+2077 SUPERSCRIPT SEVEN|"7" U+0037 DIGIT SEVEN|
|"⁸" U+2078 SUPERSCRIPT EIGHT|"8" U+0038 DIGIT EIGHT|
|"⁹" U+2079 SUPERSCRIPT NINE|"9" U+0039 DIGIT NINE|
fields.summary: Replace superscript digits with ASCII digits when creating a branch for a JIRA issue

fields.description:
To use the wording "needs work" can create very negative feelings for the author of a pull request. As a reviewer I simply want to mark a PR as not being done but I definitly don't want to show off that this PR needs work.


Most of the times a reviewer simply waits for changes which is also my intention of this suggestion:
Please rename the wording of "needs work" to something like:
"waiting for changes" "awaiting changes" "improvement requested"

The goal is to ommit frustration on the authors side and improve PRs by using non violent communication. 

There are definitely other wordings that might be better, but at least I hope my intentions are clear.
fields.summary: Pull Request change "Needs Work" wording

*Problem Definition*
 Presently in Bitbucket Server, when creating a fork, the checkbox to _Enable fork syncing_ is checked by default. 

*Suggested Solution*
 When Forking "Enable fork syncing" checkbox should not be checked by default. A global or project/repository level option could be added to toggle the default state of this option. 

*Workaround*
 The only workaround is to manually uncheck the _Enable fork syncing_ if this is not needed by developers.
fields.summary: Add an option to disable fork syncing by default when forking a repository

fields.description:
Currently Bitbucket sends a crushing amount of emails regarding pull requests, and it's hard to find the useful ones through all the noise. It seems like there are a handful of events that trigger emails, and it would be good if the user could choose to be notified about only the ones they care about:
 * Someone adds me to a pull request
 * Someone approves/denies/etc's a pull request 
 * Someone comments on a pull request
 * Someone merges a pull request
 * Someone adds commits to a pull request.

I could also see the use case to scope these settings by: 
 * Pull requests I'm reviewing\watching
 * Pull requests I created

Since someone may care more about approvals and such on their OWN PRs, versus other peoples'.

fields.description:
Hi,

 

I am referring the below article to setup and configure remote elasticsearch node for Bitbucket DC 5.3 on CentOS 7.

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver053/install-and-configure-a-remote-elasticsearch-instance-938023020.html]

It mentions - 
 # Create a directory called {{buckler}} within the {{elasticsearch/config}} directory. 


 # Within the {{elasticsearch/config}} directory, create a file named {{buckler.yml}}. 

 

I created the same under /usr/share/elasticsearch/config directory.

 

But when I start Elasticsearch, I see the warning in the log file

 

Oct 11 09:35:07 gvastict101.temenos.com elasticsearch[31197]: [2018-10-11 09:35:07,418][WARN ][com.atlassian.elasticsearch.buckler.config.BucklerConfig] Buckler config file missing, tried path: /etc/elasticsearch/buckler/buckler.yml

 

This implies that Elasticsearch did not pickup the config file for Buckler.

 

On digging further in the ES website URL - 

[https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/2.3/setup-dir-layout.html]

I understand that by default the conf directory is "/etc/elasticsearch/" and therefore either I create the buckler directory under this location. OR continue to create under /usr/share/elasticsearch/ but change the default location for conf directory in the elasticsearch.yml file.

 

I feel the documentation has to make this clear.

 

Regards,

Prince
fields.summary: Incorrect location mentioned for buckler.yml config file in Bitbucket install steps on "Install and configure a remote elasticsearch instance"

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The {{DefaultLicensedUserCountCache}} job is scheduled by multiple nodes concurrently, causing Bitbucket to throw a {{PK_BB_CLUSTEREDJOB unique constraint violated}} error in the logs.

Since it is expected that multiple nodes will schedule the job at the same time, the error should not be logged.

(i) While waiting for this fix, it is safe to ignore this error since there are no impacts on the functionalities.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Bitbucket receives an event that triggers the job to be scheduled

(i) the move to a new delegated user directory can increase the frequency of these errors. In fact, the {{DefaultLicensedUserCountCache}} job will be triggered at every login that causes a new user to be created/authorized to access Bitbucket.

h3. Expected Results
No errors are returned.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bitbucket.log file

In case of an +Oracle+ database:
{noformat}
DEBUG [topic-dispatcher:thread-1]  c.a.s.i.l.DefaultLicensedUserCountCache Received cache update 100 from cluster node <node ip> 750 ms since the last recalculation, recalculating in 60000 ms
INFO  [topic-dispatcher:thread-1]  o.h.e.j.b.internal.AbstractBatchImpl HHH000010: On release of batch it still contained JDBC statements
ERROR [topic-dispatcher:thread-1]  o.h.e.j.batch.internal.BatchingBatch HHH000315: Exception executing batch [java.sql.BatchUpdateException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (BITBUCKET.PK_BB_CLUSTEREDJOB) violated
], SQL: insert into bb_clusteredjob (job_runner_key, next_run, parameters, version, first_run, interval_millis, sched_type, job_id) values (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, 1, ?)
WARN  [topic-dispatcher:thread-1]  o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper SQL Error: 1, SQLState: 23000
ERROR [topic-dispatcher:thread-1]  o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper ORA-00001: unique constraint (BITBUCKET.PK_BB_CLUSTEREDJOB) violated
{noformat}

In case of a +PostgreSQL+ database:
{noformat}
ERROR [hz.hazelcast.event-4]  o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper Batch entry 0 insert into bb_clusteredjob (job_runner_key, next_run, parameters, version, first_run, interval_millis, sched_type, job_id) values ('com.atlassian.stash.internal.license.DefaultLicensedUserCountCache', '2018-01-01 00:00:01.000000+00'::timestamp with time zone, NULL, 1, '2018-01-01 00:00:01.000000+00'::timestamp with time zone, 0, 1, 'DefaultLicensedUserCountCache') was aborted: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "pk_bb_clusteredjob"
  Detail: Key (job_id)=(DefaultLicensedUserCountCache) already exists.  Call getNextException to see other errors in the batch.
WARN  [hz.hazelcast.event-4]  o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
ERROR [hz.hazelcast.event-4]  o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "pk_bb_clusteredjob"
  Detail: Key (job_id)=(DefaultLicensedUserCountCache) already exists.
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
When this error occurs, there are no issues with the cluster itself or with nodes unexpectedly leaving the cluster.

h3.Workaround
Not available.
fields.summary: Scheduling the DefaultLicensedUserCountCache from multiples node in a cluster causes a unique constraint violation on the pk_bb_clusteredjob constraint

fields.description:
One can know whether a private repo exists with the following approach:

Open [https://bitbucket.org/t1016d/test/src] with your browser. Since this repo (t1016d/test) exists, you'll be redirect to login page.

On the other hand, open [https://bitbucket.org/t1016d/test1/src]. Since there's no such repo, you'll get 404 Not found.

 

I'm not sure how critical this issue is. At least, I know such approach isn't applicable on GitHub.
fields.summary: Leaking the existence of private repos

fields.description:
As per the Bitbucket AWS Documentation and the supported Cloud Formation Templates, the recommended setup is to have active-active nodes across availability zones.

Please see the documentation at [https://aws.amazon.com/quickstart/architecture/bitbucket/]
 !Screen Shot 2018-10-03 at 18.55.54.png|width=400!

The diagram suggests having active nodes across Availability Zone 1 and Availability Zone 2.

However, Atlassian support team does not recommend this configuration. As per support, one of the availability zones is meant to be a cold stand-by. 

As a customer, I would expect the product to work as per the published architecture diagram to ensure high-availability across availability zones.

Please watch this issue regarding the documentation fix pending for the bug BSERV-11404
fields.summary: Support for Active Nodes across availability zones in AWS
